items.content_html:
Summary

Fix #13703 by improving/expanding the X-Forwarded-For description and guidance to help prevent readers from misusing it.

Please note: All of the changes in this PR also apply to the Forwarded header. I can adapt these changes to that header as well, but I thought I should get feedback from MDN first.

Motivation

As described in the issue, it is easy to make mistakes using the XFF header that can easily lead to security vulnerabilities. (And this is actually quite common.)

Supporting details

items.content_html:
Summary

I have checked and Proxy.preventExtensions and it also intercepts Object.seal & Object.freeze, so I included those functions in "Interceptions" section.

Motivation

Supporting details

const sealProxy = new Proxy({}, {
    preventExtensions: function(target) {
        console.log('seal called');
        Object.preventExtensions(target);
        return true;
    }
});
Object.seal(sealProxy);

const freezeProxy = new Proxy({}, {
    preventExtensions: function(target) {
        console.log('freeze called');
        Object.preventExtensions(target);
        return true;
    }
});
Object.freeze(freezeProxy);

Related issues

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: proxy preventExtensions intercepts seal & freeze

items.content_html:
This PR is a continuation off of #13347. This PR replaces all of the calls to the {{arch}} macro with Markdown links, using a simple find-and-replace script. This will allow us to remove the macro from MDN entirely. The script takes into account the second variable passed in as display text as well.

Script used:

import {promises as fs} from "fs";
import path from "path";

// https://gist.github.com/lovasoa/8691344
async function* walk(dir) {
	for await (const d of await fs.opendir(dir)) {
		const entry = path.join(dir, d.name);
		if (d.isDirectory()) yield* walk(entry);
		else if (d.isFile() && d.name != ".DS_Store") yield entry;
	}
}
// END SNIPPET

const re = /([\w"]+>[\w\s]*)?(`)?(?<!\\){{anch\("([^"]*)"(?:, "([^"]*)")?\)}}(?:`)?/g;

const main = async () => {
	for await (const p of walk((`${process.env.HOME}/Developer/Gooborg/mdn-content/files`))) {
		const isHTMLFile = p.endsWith('.html');
		let contents = await fs.readFile(p, 'utf-8');
		let changed = false;

		const matches = [...contents.matchAll(re)];
		for (const match of matches) {
			const isHTML = isHTMLFile || !!match[1];

			let text = match[4] || match[3];
			if (match[2]) text = isHTML ? `<code>${text}</code>` : `\`${text}\``;
			const link = match[3]
				.replace(/\n\//g, '')
				.replace(/[\s\(\)]/g, '_')
				.replace(/_+/g, '_')
				.toLowerCase();
			const anchor = isHTML ? `<a href="#${link}">${text}</a>` : `[${text}](#${link})`;

			changed = true;
			contents = contents.replace(match[0], (match[1] || '') + anchor);
		}

		if (changed) {
			await fs.writeFile(p, contents);
		}
	}
}

await main();

Notice: this is definitely a big PR, and I'm happy to split into smaller chunks if desired.
items.title: Replace {{anch}} macro with Markdown links

items.content_html:
Summary

I'm referring to PR #13704 because I screwed up quite a bit there and couldn't fix the errors.

With this PR everything should work now (I really hope).

Changed following like discussed in Issue #11932 :

  • first moved document using "yarn content move..."
  • title changed (I couldn't think of anything better and didn't really find a consistent pattern in the naming of the assessment pages - but I'm open to other suggestions :)
  • added two additional tags
  • content adjusted in a few places
  • content/sections rearranged to fit with the pattern of the other assessment pages
  • added assessments section to the modules overview page

I think the mistake was that instead of moving the document at the beginning (before changes in the md files where made), I moved it at the very end....

What remains to be determined:

  • I've had the question several times and still don't know where the "Assessment:" prefix in the navigation/sidebar left of the page comes from? Is this added automatically or must something be done here?
  • In the issue we also mentioned the marking guides, but tbh I don't know much about them and what the requirements are etc. so I haven't done anything on that

Motivation

This PR should replace the one mentioned.

Supporting details

PR #13704 & Issue #11932

Related issues

items.content_html:
Summary

The "accessability concerns" section references an issue which was fixed in Chrome 90, as if it applied to current browser versions. The reference given for the issue itself - https://marcysutton.com/content-visibility-accessible-semantics - has been updated to note that it's no longer an issue.

This describes the current behavior, while noting the past behavior prior to Chrome 90. Follow's Google's own description - https://web.dev/content-visibility/#a-note-on-accessibility

Motivation

It's important that information relative to accessability on MDN be up to date, both for users and to maintain trust in MDN's information.

Supporting details

https://web.dev/content-visibility/#a-note-on-accessibility
https://marcysutton.com/content-visibility-accessible-semantics

Related issues

N/A

  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error

items.content_html:
Summary

Remove the outdated learning area release notes page and the "What's new?" section on the main page.

Motivation

This "What's new" is placed quite prominently on the main Learning Area page and hasn't been updated since June 2020. Either we update it (for example, mention @wbamberg's work), or we remove it entirely. I don't think it adds that much value, so this PR proposes to remove it.

A link to the discourse is provided later in the page under "Contact us", so I removed that sentence, too.
items.title: Remove learning area release notes

items.content_html:
Summary

This change replaces the use of the var with let in the code snippets and examples within the web extension section. This addresses the requirement identified in "Replace var with let in code snippets and examples" #11343 (which in tern was originally identified in discussions on "Use const in place of var" #11135).

After completing the global search and replace, all the files were checked. This discovered:

  • one occurrence within a CSS example (on the theme_experiment page) that was reverted
  • code blocks incorrectly tagged with json on Work with contextual identities which were also corrected.

items.content_html:
Summary

This piece will help the reader understand how arra.sort() works internally. As a beginner, we have question on how sort() function is comparing two values and then add it to array.

Motivation

I know many sorting algorithims and how they work. But there was no explanation of how array.sort() works internally in JavaScript. It just said that based on return value of compareFunction ( <0 , >0 , === 1) it will sort. But element element implementation was not there. Mainly because sort() does not have fixed implementation. Still I have added a code snippet that will help reader to understand in depth

Supporting details

Related issues

items.title: Update: Internal implemenation of array.sort()
